ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Just general ideas about the problem of evil, really, and the seemingly un-satisfyingly-answerable aspect of theodicies.
Improved ability to do independent research and bring external questions and reflections to class.
Ability to engage in high-level philosophical and theological discourse.
I can accept free will without adopting the free will defense.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the topics were interesting
Weaknesses: incredibly poorly organized which caused the class to rehash old arguments over and over and over again with little engagement from the students who did not have sufficient time to read the materials being discussed

Strengths: An avuncular professor with a deep and personal investment in the primary topic of the course. A professor willing to countenance strong objections to his perspective and entertain alternative perspectives. A professor who exhibited humility about his personal and academic positionality within the literature. A professor willing to share his personal perspective about the course material whenever prompted and who genuinely valued student input. 

Weaknesses: A non-existent syllabus. Many readings were not announced until 18-36 hours before the seminar. 95 percent of the class never spoke once throughout the entire course and were never prompted to speak. The lack of a syllabus meant the course never exhibited clear direction and too much of class entailed discursive reminiscence. Virtually no interdisciplinary literature was assigned or even acknowledged. With few early exceptions, all of the readings derived from Analytic philosophy's theodicy subfield. Theology, literature, autobiography, psychology, phenomenology --none of these intruded into a class about suffering. The complete lack of student participation necessitated the seminar transform into a quasi-lecture format. This class desperately needs a clear and detailed syllabus. It also needs a plurality of voices and perspectives about suffering --not just the exclusive perspective of a handful of Analytic philosophers.
It's a bit disorganized but the content of the lecture was extremely good and discussion in class was engaging.

Strengths: Very well led; instructor always made sure we were prepared.

Weaknesses: Somewhat repetitive; some discussions felt like they were covering old territory again.
It is rather disorganized and I think the best way to improve it is to go into the details of each reading, and unpack the arguments that are written out.

The course was an interesting way to explore some incredibly difficult topics. I left feeling a bit unsatisfied, but that is to be expected when exploring the reason for suffering, and overall thought our professors did a good job of laying out potential answers through the theodicies of different thinkers. I do believe this course could be improved with a bit more structure/organization, and possibly sending out the readings earlier in the week. I appreciated that the professors were both very approachable and honest throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not likely. What I gleaned from my time in the course could be picked up by just reading the syllabus' very sparse readings list on one's own.
No. Not unless they have a fanatical Analytic interest in the subject material and are comfortable doing independent research to supplement a non-existent syllabus.
Yes. I learned a great ton in this class.
Yes if they are interested in theology and philosophy of religion.
No, because it is hard to learn things effectively in class.
